name: patronymic
content:

a name that is based on the given name (= the name given at birth) of someone's father or one of their father's ancestors: Numerous patronymics of later formation have lasted: Johnson, Jackson, Peterson. The second Cossack addresses the first by his patronymic ("son of Eremey"). Compare
matronymic noun
More examplesFewer examplesA patronymic can be based on a full name (William-s) or a nickname (Will-s).Many family names are patronymics, so called because they are based on the first name of some long-ago father.Pressed by journalists, the guide still refuses to give his name, offering only his first name and patronymic, "Valery Georgiyevich".

(of a name) based on the given name (= the name given at birth) of someone's father or one of their father's ancestors: Patronymic names, such as Robson, Richardson and Jackson, are based on the given name of a person's father. The patronymic form D'Amanti was given to the children of such unions. Compare
matronymic adjective
More examplesFewer examplesPaulsen is a Scandinavian patronymic surname, from the given name Paul."Respected Vladimir Vladimirovich!" read the letter, using the president's patronymic middle name as a show of respect.In the past, most European Jews didn't have surnames, instead taking patronymic names such as "David, son of Saul".
